content.headline: Understanding Medication Research and Safety During Pregnancy
content.intro: Pregnant and lactating women have historically been excluded from clinical drug research, leading to most medications being used 'off-label' during pregnancy. Recent changes aim to improve safety data for medications used during pregnancy and lactation.

sections.title: The Challenge of Medication Use in Pregnancy
sections.content: Current landscape of medication safety during pregnancy:
points: 40-60% of pregnant women take 1 or more prescription medications
Over 90% of medications lack appropriate labeling for pregnancy use
Most medications are used 'off-label' during pregnancy
Pregnant women were historically excluded from clinical trials

sections.title: Historical Context and Changes
sections.content: Evolution of medication safety research in pregnancy:
points: 1977 FDA guidelines prevented pregnant women from clinical trials
1993 NIH Revitalization Act required inclusion of women in research
Recent removal of 'vulnerable' classification for pregnant women
Increased focus on preexisting conditions in pregnancy

sections.title: Current Research Initiatives
sections.content: Efforts to improve medication safety data:
points: Studying pharmacokinetics of common pregnancy medications
Research on diabetes, hypertension, and infection treatments
Focus on individualized dosing during pregnancy

sections.title: Important Considerations
sections.content: What every pregnant woman should know about medications:
points: Always consult your provider before taking any medication
Discuss preexisting conditions and necessary medications early
Understand that medication needs may change during pregnancy
Ask about latest research on specific medications you need
